-The verb form is changed to agree with the subject.
-The preposition was changed. This is a stylistic edit.

- "Stay in" was changed to "staying at." The gerund form of the verb 'stay' was used to create parallelism with 'going out.' The prepositions 'in' and 'at' both refer to location, but 'in' is more general while 'at' is more specific.
- The phrase "all the time" is changed to "the whole time." This is an optional change, and the meanings are nearly identical in this context.

- The preposition "at" was added because "at" is used to discuss a specific time frame.
-To indicate time, the period was changed to a colon to separate hours and minutes.

- "Summer of" was inserted before "2008" and "summer" was removed from after "2008" to produce the phrase, "summer of 2008." This slight change improved the natural flow of the sentence.
- A comma was inserted before "Aris" to separate a name.
-The correct spelling is "The."
- Changing "north-eastern" fixes a spelling error, and it is capitalized because it is referring to a well-known areas in the country.
- A comma was added because "and" is separating two independent clauses.
-Added a comma, which is necessary before a conjunction joining two independent clauses.

- "complaint" was changed to "complain" because a verb is required after "shouldn't."
- "lost" was changed to "loss" because a noun is required after "their."

- "The" added before "internet." The word usually appears with "the."
- Spelling of "internet" corrected.
- Spelling of "because" corrected.
- "There" removed for clarity and conciseness.
- Comma added before "which." A comma is frequently used to introduce this type of clause.

- "The theatre" was changed to "theater ," as the later is the standard American English spelling. 
- "Students" was changed to "student" as it is being used as to describe the noun "activities."
-A comma was inserted before and after the name "Ayumi Hamasaki" to separate this nonessential phrase, which provides extra information, from the main clause.
- The comma and coordinating conjunction were replaced with a semicolon. Both options of combining two independent clauses are acceptable.

-This stylistic edit makes the sentence active voice, which is often preferable.
-This stylistic edit fits "web traffic" better because "web traffic" isn't an agent.

- "Labelling" was changed to "label." First, "labelling" is not a spelling choice in American English. Secondly, the noun form of this word is a better choice. "The" was added as a determiner for this singular noun.

- "Has" replaces "have" because the noun to which it refers is singular. 
- The verb "lose" is inserted in place of the noun "loss," as the verb is needed to state the purpose.
- A comma is removed because the following phrase is dependent on the previous phrase.
- "And" is the correct spelling of "an."
- The apostrophe "'s" outside the double quotation marks was placed inside the quotation marks because the possessive noun is formed by adding the apostrophe "'s" to the noun,  as in "Unstoppable's."

- The first word of the sentence was capitalized.
- The phrase "there is" was removed and replaced with a comma to introduce a clause with extra detail about the main subject.
- The preposition "of" was replaced with "than." This construction gives a sense of comparison and emphasis.
- The word "ago" was added to convey the sense of projection backward in time.

- A hyphen was added to "home-grown." Hyphens are required for compound adjectives when they are before a noun.
- A comma was added after "Danny White." It is generally required that there be commas on both sides of phrases starting with "like" when they give specifics in cases like this.
-"Then" was removed from the sentence since we usually use "then" to convey that this action happened after a previous action.
-"Like" is deleted to improve conciseness.
"Recognized" is the American English spelling of "recognised."
- "Metronome" is used as a common noun. Common nouns do not need to be capitalized.

-A comma is needed when a conjunction joins two clauses.
-"that evening" is idiomatically acting as an adverb, so a preposition is not needed, and "at" has been removed.
- "Learnt" was changed to the American English Standard "learned."
-A comma was inserted before the conjunction "and." We use commas before conjunctions in order to join two independent clauses.

- The word order was changed to improve the fluency and clarity of the sentence. So "also would like" was changed to "would also like."
- The preposition "on" was replaced with the noun "lesson" because the noun phrase needs to have a noun.

- The words "out" and "spoken" were combined to produce the correctly spelled "outspoken."
- The words "self" and "mutalation" were hyphenated to produce the correctly spelled "self-mutilation."

-"along" was replaced with the more sensible "around."
-"Hu" was made into a possessive.
- "Succeeded" is the correct spelling of "succeded."

- The comma was removed because the second half of the sentence does not have a new subject.
- "Liaison" is the correct spelling of "liason."

-This edit adds a comma to delineate the thousands place in this number.
-This edit makes 'golf' lower case because it is a common noun.
-This edit adds an Oxford comma because it is Grammarly's preferred convention.

-An unnecessary space before an apostrophe has been removed.
-A comma was added before a conjunction joining two clauses.
-The preposition "by" was added since "join" can't take an object.
- As three words that come before the noun and function together as an adjective to describe "bands," "up and coming" were combined and hyphenated to produce "up-and-coming."

- A comma was inserted to separate two independent questions within the sentence.
- "That will" was changed to "will that" because in English, the question word always comes first.

- "some" was removed because it's not necessary and removing it improves the flow of the sentence.
- A comma was added after technology because commas are added after introductory phrases in English. 
- "be" was added because a verb is needed to make the sentence grammatical.
